Headline.Para: It's Spring! (No, It Isn't.) Yes, It Is!

Snippet.Para: People, did you enjoy it while it lasted -- spring?
Even if it surfaced for only one day before winter returned in buckets, wasn't it a thing to behold?

DocData.PubEdition: The New York Times on the Web

Headline.Para: It's Spring! (No, It Isn't.) Yes, It Is!

LeadPara.Para: People, did you enjoy it while it lasted -- spring?
Even if it surfaced for only one day before winter returned in buckets, wasn't it a thing to behold?

TailParas.Para: To mark the season's first day, we sent five photographers to document it throughout the five boroughs -- in nature and fashion, in courtship and recreation and shopping. Visions of short shorts and food carts danced in the photographers' heads: Frisbees arcing over Central Park, ospreys returning to Jamaica Bay, couples flirting on the Staten Island Ferry, crocuses waking from their annual slumber.
Welcome, instead, to the first day of spring 2018.
The Bronx
Photos by Elias Williams

To Elias Williams, who set out to cover nature in the Bronx, spring means the arrival of the color green, which he associates with calm and mental health. ''It's one step closer to summer and things that represent summer,'' he said. That will have to wait. This year, Mr. Williams looked up and found man-made blooms and plumage -- bursts of color holding space for the real thing. Calm and mental health can come later. This is New York, after all.
Staten Island
Photos by An Rong Xu

The thing about spring is that ''things are in flux,'' said An Rong Xu, who set out to capture spring's arrival in the fashions of Staten Island. ''The city starts getting more crowded, everything's heating up, and summer hits before you get to enjoy spring.
''It's a mixed blessing.''
Prudent residents of the island found someplace warm to curl up, but this left the streets to the daring, and to colors that did not care who was watching.
Manhattan
Photos by Andres Kudacki

In Manhattan, where Andres Kudacki sought the jubilance of spring retail fever, he found instead people stocking provisions against more winter. ''Very gray and depressed,'' he said. Mr. Kudacki, who grew up in Argentina and recently lived in Spain, was looking forward to his third spring in New York. And he will no doubt get it.
Eventually.
Brooklyn
Photos by Adrienne Grunwald

''I was an athlete, so the weather change is about that transfer from indoors to outside,'' said Adrienne Grunwald, who photographed leisure in Brooklyn. ''It's still too chilly, but you're happy to get out of that gym. There's a sense of relief. It feels like we're all starting again, getting a fresh start. But you have to run around to get warmed up.''

This year kept even the athletes from lacing up, she said. ''I was really looking for the few moments of hope or promise perhaps that warmer days would soon be coming,'' she said. ''I did find hints along the way photographing curlers, ice skaters, beach/boardwalk walkers, high school softball teammates at practice, soccer practice, et cetera. But it definitely felt more like winter overall.''
Queens
Photos by Amy Lombard

For Amy Lombard, who was looking for love in all the Queens places, if the weather stayed warm all year long it would be just fine. ''People want to be outside with people,'' she said of spring's arrival. ''With that first warm day, everyone is a million times nicer. I don't know anyone who's had an easy winter, whether you're talking about the news or the weather. Just life. This is getting ridiculous.''
So she found spots where love flourishes in all weather conditions, including the potions in the window of her local botanica.
Spring will come, of course. It always does -- usually arriving too late and leaving too early. Which is what makes it precious, even when it plays hard to get.
Happy Nowruz, everyone! And as you face the cold, remember, nothing lasts forever. Except, of course, the marshmallow Peeps in the drugstore window.
